messages: aee07ad8cfc0fc0f3ca649d4678bd1b7 (03:18): I'm going through and helping out extending the autocomplete for an editor and they wanted to put all css3 in... is user-select in the spec? It says it was superseded by a newer document that lacks user-select.
aee07ad8cfc0fc0f3ca649d4678bd1b7 (03:19): So am I to believe that if it doesn't exist in http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-ui/ it shouldn't be added?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (03:20): For now, yes.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (03:20): Also, css3-ui isn't really supported now, though it's picked up an active editor again.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (03:21): (Supposedly.)
aee07ad8cfc0fc0f3ca649d4678bd1b7 (03:21): Well they added all the -prefixes and wanted to just keep them in and just remove them if they don't make it through later on.
aee07ad8cfc0fc0f3ca649d4678bd1b7 (03:22): I'm leaving user-select out and all the ones not in it till later.
aee07ad8cfc0fc0f3ca649d4678bd1b7 (03:22): Thanks. :D
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (03:35): Hm.  Anyone know why I'm seeing an assymmetry here?  The code should be perfectly symmetrical.  www.xanthir.com/test.html
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (03:35): is testing true gaussian blurs.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:35): cool to see paul_irish getting a hat tip in http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/07/15/the-css-corner-better-web-typography-for-better-design.aspx
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:35): bravo Sylvain
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (03:36): For whatever reason, the white half blurs wider than the black half.
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (03:40): What is the difference between the <head> and <header> tags?
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (03:40): I know head is required but I always put all my header info in there.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:40): they are in no way similar other than by name :-)

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (03:40): <head> marks the section of the html document that holds metadata and isn't displayed.  <header> is just a way of marking up a header section in your content.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:40): what tab said
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (03:41): Ah so I shouldn't put anything else in head, thanks I'll move it all to a <header> tag.
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (03:42): Should I move scripts out of header also?
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (03:42): head I mean
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (03:42): scripts should go in <head>.
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (03:42): OK, thanks again.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): basically anything that you can see in the browser goes in the <body>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): and <header> goes in the <body>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): <head> goes before the <body>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): <header> is a bit like <div>, it's just for heading-related things like <h1>, or the publication date, or whatnot
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): the spec has a number of examples
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): http://whatwg.org/html5
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): search for <header>

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (04:03): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: pity they didn‚Äôt link to Craig Mod‚Äôs @font-face example page, but I guess it would have made theirs look somewhat tame in comparison
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:03): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: add a comment
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (04:03): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: no fallbacks so no x-browser compat either
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:04): big whoop
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (04:04): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: well, they‚Äôre demoing WOFF, not @font-face (despite talking about it)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:05): who cares about x-browser compat?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:12): Dammit, it looks like my problem is float accuracy.  >_<
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:12): I hate it when that happens.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:13): I guess losing about 8 bits of accuracy when juggling white pixels is significant here.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:16): Yay, fixed!
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:17): (By cheating - when I'm on the white side, I invert pixel values so the calculations have the same accuracy as the white side.)
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (04:17): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: not browser makers when doing tech demos, that‚Äôs fer sure
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (04:25): Is it true that in html5 you don't use self closing tags? For example <br /> is just <br>
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:25): Yes, that was the original syntax for void element (those without end tags).  XML invented the <br/> syntax.
e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:25): 274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea, in the non-XML version: yes
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:26): So, as long as you're using the HTML serialization of HTML, yes.  If you're using the XML serialization, no.
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (04:26): OK, I'm not using XML serialization. Thanks gotta fix that.
e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:27): 274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea, IIRC it doesn't actually matter in the non XML version. IE they both work

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:27): In the HTML serialization you're *allowed* to use the <br/> syntax on void elements.  (You can't use it on normal elements that just happen to be empty - <div/> in the HTML serialization is just treated as a <div> open tag).
e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:28): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, in the XML serialization <div/> is counted as having an open and a closed tag ?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:29): In XML, <div/> is the same as <div></div>.
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (04:29): Good to know although I most likely wont use it. :p
e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:30): Someone really needs to write a "html5 for the web author" document.
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (04:30): I've never liked xml for some reason.
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (04:30): I avoid it whenever possible.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:30): Good idea in general.

e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:31): 274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea, XML is perfectly fine for a particular type of content. The problem comes when people try to use XML for a type of content it isn't made for
e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:31): XML is great when you have an exact format with specific data that must be sent with particular datatypes
e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:32): its horid for dyamic loosly formed content like HTML
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (04:32): e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26: I believe your referring to visual studio using it to replace ini?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (04:32): XML isn't great even for that - too many meaningless restrictions that bork the document if you mess them up.
e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:33): 274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea, nope: my sole use for XML ever was for writing an FAQ. I had a series of Sections, questions, and answers
e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26 (04:33): and I used XSLT to convert it to HTML
274af6c0d5b4ad98d9cb4a97f31866ea (04:36): e04aa5104d082e4a51d241391941ba26: *shrug* It's a good use of XML although like I said I really hate XML and I would have looked for another way
